awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the participation of graduate students, early-career researchers, and members of groups underrepresented in statistics in the International Chinese Statistical Association (ICSA) 2023 Applied Statistics Symposium, with the theme “Statistical Learning and Reasoning from Data to Knowledge”, held at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan, from June 11 – June 14, 2023. The event serves as the 32nd official annual meeting of ICSA. The main objective of the conference is to bring together both well-established and junior researchers, as well as students, from around the world who are actively pursuing theoretical and methodological research in statistics, biostatistics, data sciences and their applications in various allied fields. It provides the broader statistical community with a great opportunity to network and exchange ideas of recent developments in statistical theory, methodology, and applications.
 
The format of the conference includes multiple plenary talks, invited sessions, student paper competitions, contributed posters and short courses. The organizers strive to enhance diversity of speakers and maintain a healthy inclusive atmosphere. In addition, a special panel discussion will be organized on mentoring and career development, especially geared toward women and researchers from groups underrepresented in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM). For students, the conference will provide opportunities such as a student paper competition and contributed poster sessions. The website with details about the symposium is symposium2023.icsa.org

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF conference funding is for a four-day international conference, titled “ICSA 2023 Applied Statistics Symposium: Statistical learning and reasoning from data to knowledge.” The conference took place at the Michigan League Building at the University of Michigan (UM), Ann Arbor, Michigan, from June 11 – June 14, 2023.  The event serves as the 32nd official annual meeting of ICSA. The main objective of the conference is to bring together both well-established and junior researchers, as well as students, from around the world who are actively pursuing theoretical and methodological research in statistics, biostatistics, data sciences and their applications in various allied fields. It provided the broader statistical community with a great opportunity to network and exchange ideas of recent developments in statistical theory, methodology, and applications.

The scientific program spans a wide range of topics ranging from the fundamentals of statistical theory to computationally-intensive methods and scientific application oriented data modeling, through a number of sessions classified as plenary, special invited, invited, student paper competition, posters, and panel discussions. In particular, the program consists of three plenary talks and one banquet speaker, each of one hour duration by

  • Dr. Sylvia Collins (U.S. Food and Drug Administration)
  • Prof. Kathryn Roeder (Carnegie Mellon University)
  • Prof. Ming Yuan (Columbia University)
  • Prof. Qiwei Yao (London School of Economics and Political Science, Banquet Speaker)

The conference had eight short courses, including 

  1. Causal Inference in Randomized Controlled Trials: New Challenges and Perspectives
  2. Statistical and Computational Methods for Microbiome Data Analysis
  3. Win Statistics (Win Ratio, Win Odds and Net Benefit): Introduction, Properties, Implementations, and Applications
  4. On the Memory and Speed Scalability of Spectral Clustering
  5. Instrumental Variable Methods for Causal Inference with Applications to Mendelian
  6.  Randomization Modeling and Analysis of Cancer Screening Data
  7. Bayesian Networks and Applications
  8. Applied Event Time Data Analysis with R

Moreover, the conference had 118 invited sessions, with each of 4 talks and 100 minutes duration. Among them, there were 2 student paper award sessions and 3 career panel sessions. The topics of invited sessions were be extremely diverse, and included cutting edge research in both emerging as well as established fields. The invited session topics included artificial intelligence in the big data era, recent developments in functional data analysis, statistical methods and applications in health economics and outcome research, and current and future trends of data science, testing and estimation problems in big data, efficient computational methods for large spatial data, high-dimensional covariance matrix modeling, random matrix theory and applications, precision medicine, wearable computing, electronic health records, empirical likelihood, survey sampling, graphical models, causal inference, climate science, adaptive clinical trial design and many others.

The conference promotes education, research and application of statistics, probability and data science in Michigan, fosters the exchange of information and scholarly activities between various countries as well as among other national/international organizations for the development of Statistical Science, serves towards the needs of local young statisticians and data scientists and will encourage cooperative efforts among members in education, research, industry, and business. 

The conference was well received and brought together both well-established and emerging young researchers, as well as students, from around the world who are actively pursuing theoretical and methodological research in statistics/biostatistics and data science and their applications in various allied fields. Overall, the conference attracted 625 attendees from academia, industry, and government sectors to Ann Arbor, among which 149 (24%) were students. It included 4 keynote talks, 8 short courses, and 118 invited sessions, among which there were 2 student paper award sessions and 3 career panel sessions, and a student poster session with 47 posters. In particular, the conference gave five student paper awards and one Jiann-Ping Hsu Pharmaceutical and Regulatory Sciences Student Paper. In addition, it gave 5 honorable mentions. The conference also gave 4 poster awards and 6 honorable mentions. 

The conference also had a significant impact on training and professional development and promotion of diversity and engagement of women, minorities, and persons with disabilities. We made a strong effort to increase diversity while forming the international program committee and preparing the program. Two of our three keynote speakers were women. Many of the other speakers (including invited Young Researchers) as well as many committee members and session organizers were women. Industry and government representation have been ensured in various committees. Women and minorities were also invited to chair scientific sessions. The NSF support was used to support young researchers and graduate students, women and minorities and underrepresented groups. The scientific program provided a forum for building new collaborations between researchers from the major areas of current research in statistics, data science, and probability and between researchers from the United States and from around the world, which will immensely enhance nation's human resource development efforts.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/12/2024
Modified by: Jian Kang
